column1: Redwood City is a city on the San Francisco Peninsula in Northern California's Bay Area
column2: approximately 27 miles (43 km) south of San Francisco
column3: and 24 miles (39 km) northwest of San Jose. Redwood City's history spans its earliest inhabitation by the Ohlone people to being a port for lumber and other goods. The county seat of San Mateo County in the heart of Silicon Valley
column4: Redwood City is home to several global technology companies including Oracle
column8: and Informatica. The city had an estimated population of 85
column9: 925 in 2019. The Port of Redwood City is the only deepwater port on San Francisco Bay south of San Francisco. Redwood City is the location of the San Mateo County Jail
column10: for both women and men. The Hetch Hetchy water pipeline runs through Redwood City and supplies a vast majority of the surrounding area with low grain (+/− 3 grains) rated water.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has an area of 34.7 square miles (90 km2)
column3: of which 19.4 square miles (50 km2) is land and 15.2 square miles (39 km2) (43.91%) is water.  A major watercourse draining much of Redwood City is Redwood Creek
column4: to which several significant river deltas connect
column5: the largest of which is Westpoint Slough.

column1: Redwood City stretches from the San Francisco Bay towards the Santa Cruz Mountains between San Carlos to the northwest and Atherton to the southeast with Woodside to the southwest.  It is divided by Highway 101 and further inland El Camino Real on the northwest/southeast axis and Woodside Road on the north-northeast/south-southwest axis.  Locally
column2: the former two are regarded as north/south and the latter east/west
column3: as 101 and El Camino connects Redwood City to San Francisco and San Jose and Woodside Road runs from San Francisco Bay to the Santa Cruz Mountains.

column1: Neighborhoods include Bair Island to the northeast of Highway 101. The northern gated community of Redwood Shores also to the northeast of Highway 101 is part of Redwood City
column2: although it is not possible to travel by road from one to the other without passing through the neighboring city of San Carlos
column3: or through Belmont via unincorporated San Mateo County. Stretching along Highway 101 to the southeast of Woodside Road is Friendly Acres
column4: further inland and still to the southeast of Woodside Road are Redwood Village and then Redwood Oaks.  Most neighborhoods are to the northwest of Woodside Ride and southwest of Highway 101.  Centennial
column6: and Stambaugh Heller are adjacent to 101.  Next inland are Edgewood
column11: and Woodside Plaza.  Furthest inland is Farm Hills (or Farm Hill).Neighborhoods associated with Redwood City but not part of the incorporated city include Emerald Lake Hills  and Kensington Square inland and to the north and

column2: just north of Emerald Hills and east of San Carlos' Crestview area
column3: is another Redwood City neighborhood that is formally part of unincorporated San Mateo County.  Although Redwood City has a large middle class
column4: the southeastern section of Redwood City strongly resembles working-class North Fair Oaks in both demographic makeup and income level.

column1: In an attempt to revitalize Redwood City's downtown
column2: city officials decided to look into development. In February 1999
column3: the San Mateo County History Museum opened inside the old San Mateo County Courthouse in downtown Redwood City. The courthouse had been built in 1910 and in the late '30s an addition was built in front of the original structure
column4: obscuring the view. As part of the revitalization
column5: this addition was torn down and replaced with a large courtyard flanked by water fountains on either side
column6: leading to the main steps of the courthouse.  The courthouse's glass dome is lit at night and changes colors every 11 seconds.

column2: a 20-screen theater and various shops opened in a prime downtown location. The theater complex boasts restaurant and retail space at street level and a two-level underground parking structure.
along with most of the Bay Area
column3: enjoys a mild Mediterranean climate (Köppen climate classification Csb)
column6: relatively wet winters. The National Weather Service
column7: which maintains both a forecast center and a cooperative office in Redwood City
column8: reports that December is the coolest month and July is the warmest month. The record highest temperature of 110 °F (43 °C) was recorded on both July 14 and 15
column9: 1972. The record lowest temperature of 16 °F (−9 °C) was recorded on January 11
column11: there are an average of 21.6 days with highs of 90 °F (32 °C) or higher and 2.8 days with highs of 100 °F (38 °C) or higher; there are an average of 1.8 days with lows of 32 °F (0 °C) or lower.

column1: The normal annual precipitation is 20.56 inches (52.2 cm). The most rainfall in one month was 12.42 inches (31.5 cm) in February 1998. The record 24-hour rainfall of 4.88 inches (12.4 cm) was on October 13
column2: 1962. There are an average of 62.1 days with measurable precipitation. Snow flurries have been observed on rare occasions; there was some minor snow accumulation in May 1935

being the first city in San Mateo County to do so; it has remained the county seat since the county's formation in 1856. The land had been part of the Rancho de las Pulgas granted to the Arguello family in 1835 by the Mexican government. Their control was challenged after the Mexican–American War when California became part of the United States. The family lawyer
column4: in 1854 defended the claim somewhat successfully and was allowed to buy the part of the estate that is now Redwood City. Mezes sold some of the land to people already squatting on it along the banks of Redwood Creek and named the settlement "Mezesville." Though the city did not keep that name
column5: Mezes Park still exists on land that Mezes had given for open space.In 1907
column8: grew what may perhaps have been the first commercially grown chrysanthemums in the United States in Redwood City. In 1926
column9: the chamber of commerce proclaimed the city the "Chrysanthemum Center of the World" though the internment of Japanese Americans in 1941 and other factors would contribute to the end of flower growing as a major industry in the city.

column1: Redwood City's charter provides for a councilor-manager form of government. The City Council appoints the City Manager and adopts policies
column2: which the City Manager is expected to implement. The City Manager appoints and manages most of Redwood City's department heads (the City Clerk and City Attorney being notable exceptions).

column2: Shelly Masur (serving as Vice Mayor)
column7: and Diana Reddy. The current City Manager is Melissa Stevenson Diaz.In the California State Legislature

column14: respectively.According to the California Secretary of State

column1: It has elementary and middle schools operated by the Redwood City School District.  At the high school level it is part of the Sequoia Union High School District and high schools in Redwood City that are part of this district are the comprehensive Sequoia High School
column2: the charter schools Summit Preparatory Charter High School and Everest Public High School
column3: and the continuation school Redwood High School. Many students from Redwood City attend another Sequoia Union school
column5: in the neighboring town of Woodside. The community of Redwood Shores is served by the Belmont - Redwood Shores School District and the Carlmont High School.

column7: 000 for a new library; he gave another $6
column8: 000 in 1906 to rebuild it after it was destroyed in the earthquake.  In 1959 Schaberg library opened and was named for Hannah Schaberg who left money for its building in her will.

column2: emblazoned on arches across Broadway at the east and west entrances to downtown
column3: is "Climate Best By Government Test." This is based on a climatological survey conducted by the United States and German governments prior to World War I. The area centered on Redwood City tied for the world's best climate with the Canary Islands and North Africa's Mediterranean Coast. The local paper had a contest for a city slogan to attract new residents and Wilbur Doxsee entered “By Government Test
column4: Our Climate is Best” which won the $10 prize money in 1925.
